keyTakeAways: Steinway & Sons is a rare example of successful US manufacturing that relies on skilled craftsmanship rather than mass production.
The company maintains a high-value, premium product that allows it to charge prices up to $200,000 per grand piano, supporting its operations despite high costs.
Despite Trump’s trade tariffs, Steinway has not been significantly impacted due to domestic sourcing and the unique nature of its product.
The shortage of skilled workers, particularly in specialized trades like piano crafting, poses a long-term challenge to US manufacturing.
The company has preserved its workforce through intergenerational training and continuous operation since 1873, ensuring the survival of unique artisanal skills.
Automation and AI have reduced the need for labor in modern factories, making skilled craftsmanship even more valuable and rare.
The US manufacturing sector continues to face structural challenges, including rising costs, regulatory burdens, and uncertainty from trade policies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores how Steinway & Sons, a 150-year-old piano manufacturer in Queens, New York, remains a rare success in US manufacturing by relying on skilled craftsmanship, premium pricing, and domestic sourcing. Despite broader challenges such as high costs, trade policy uncertainty under President Donald Trump, and automation, Steinway continues to operate due to its unique value proposition and commitment to quality. The company’s 11-month piano production timeline and reliance on specialized artisans like Bernard Craddock underscore the importance of human skill in an era of machine-based production. While Trump’s tariffs have raised input costs and created economic instability, Steinway has not been significantly affected due to its domestic supply chain and high-end market. However, long-term challenges include the scarcity of Sitka spruce and the aging workforce, which necessitates intergenerational training to preserve artisanal expertise. The article raises broader questions about the future of US manufacturing, suggesting that a model based on quality, heritage, and skilled labor may offer a more sustainable path than mass production or price competition.
title: How a company from the Gilded Age could be the future of US manufacturing
